courses.name: Introduction to Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: A broad introduction to the canon of Western drama, the principles of theatre history as well as key artistic movements and notions of arts criticism through a range of dramatic texts, artistic movements, and performance practices, with particular reference to the relationship between dramatic texts and their larger contexts. This course combines weekly two-hour lectures with one-hour tutorials.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: DRM100Y1, DRE121H5, DRE122H5, VPDA10H3, VPDA11H3, VPDA10H3, VPDA15H3, VPDB10H3, VPDB11H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students must sign up for a tutorial. They will be informed of their tutorial room in the first week of class.

cmCourseInfo.description: Emphasis is initially placed on ensemble, non-verbal, and improvisational work. Students proceed to the application of their acquired skills to scripted material. Students may apply in their first or second year of University. The Application Form Deadline is March 10th for the first round of auditions; August 10th for the second round. See Audition Guidelines for information on how to apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Performance I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: An audition in April or in August. Students can apply directly out of high school.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: DRS221H5 AND DRS222H5; VPDB01H3 AND VPDB02H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on an audition, interview and/or portfolio submission. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. First round of applications were due March 10th for auditions & interviews held in April. The second round of applications are due by August 10th and auditions & interviews will be held in late August. Student can apply straight out of high school: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to major concepts and artistic practices in directing, emphasizing theoretical and historical issues with supplemental practical application. The course focuses on different styles, ideas, and goals of theatre directors in their relations to actors, audiences, and broad cultural and political contexts. The Application Deadline is March 10th for the first round of interviews; August 10th for the second round. See the Guidelines for information on how to apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Directing I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: An interview in April or in August with a letter of interest. Students can apply directly out of high school.
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1

Distribution Requirement: Humanities

Breadth Requirement: Creative and Cultural Representations (1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on an application and interview. Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. Apply online: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: An intensive study of a range of historical and cross-cultural dramatic and performance texts and practices that contextualize theatre and performance more broadly within the social, political, and cultural parameters in which they take place. Theatre history is necessarily inextricable from world history and this course considers the many ways theatre and performance interact with the globalized world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Comparative Theatre Histories
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: A hands-on study of the craft of dramatic writing. The class examines the basic elements of playwriting such as plot, structure, theme, character, dialogue, setting, with an emphasis on story-making. Attention is given to the development of students own work through written assignments and in-class exercises. The Application Deadline is March 10th for the first round; August 10th for the second round. See the Guidelines for information on how to apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Playwriting I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A portfolio of writing samples due on March 10th or August 10th. Students can apply directly out of high school.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on a portfolio submission. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. First round of applications were due March 10th. The second round of applications are due by August 10th. Apply online: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the shifting landscapes of European theatre theory, history and practice in the late 19th century and their repercussions throughout the 20th and 21st centuries. The course focuses on the developments of modern and postdramatic theatre. It also includes critical analysis of the annual Drama Mainstage production and current Canadian theatre.
cmCourseInfo.title: Concepts of Twentieth-Century Theatre
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: A practical introduction to aspects of theatre design, with a module on theatre production. Working extensively in the Helen Gardiner Phelan Playhouse, the students form the core of the production team for Drama productions. The Application Deadline is March 10th for the first round; August 10th for the second round. See department website for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Production and Design I: Production
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: An interview in April or in August. Students can apply directly out of high school. See online application for details.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on an audition, interview and/or portfolio submission. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. First round of applications were due March 10th for auditions & interviews held in April. The second round of applications are due by August 10th and auditions & interviews will be held in late August. Students can apply straight out of high school using this link: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission from the instructor.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/focus/course/rop

cmCourseInfo.description: Building upon the work of DRM200Y1, students concentrate on scene study, styles of acting, and the development of ensemble work with an intensive focus on voice and movement practices. The Application Deadline is March 10th.
cmCourseInfo.title: Performance I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1; DRM200Y1; Minimum CGPA of 2.7 and permission of the Drama Centre. See online application for more details.
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 or any course from Group A if DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 is complete; 1.0 FCE from DRM375H1/DRM376H1/ DRM377H1/DRM378H1 or permission of the Centre.
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: and the development of ensemble work with an intensive focus on voice and movement practices. The

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information on how to enrol, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: A continuation of DRM202H1, concentrating on major concepts and artistic practices in directing. The course focuses on different styles, ideas, and goals of theatre directors in their relations to actors, audiences, and broad cultural and political contexts. A major component will be the practical application of basic directing techniques. See Guidelines for information on how to apply and the deadline to apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Directing II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1; DRM202H1; Minimum CGPA of 2.7 and permission of the Centre. See online application for details.
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 or any course from Group A.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on an application. Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. Apply online by November 10th. https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: A continuation of DRM228H1, concentrating on the in-depth knowledge and practice of playwriting with an emphasis on style and technique of writing for the stage. Students develop their own work through written assignments, in-class exercises, and the final public presentation. See Portfolio Guidelines for information on how to apply and the deadline to apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Playwriting II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1; DRM228H1; Minimum CGPA of 2.7 and permission of the Centre. See online application for details.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on an audition, interview and/or portfolio submission. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. First round of applications were due March 10th for auditions & interviews held in April. The second round of applications are due by August 10th and auditions & interviews will be held in late August. Apply online: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of dramaturgical theory and of interpretations of the dramaturge's function in the theatre. Using examples from Canada and beyond, students apply this knowledge to theatre practice.
cmCourseInfo.title: Dramaturgy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: The turn of the 21st century advanced a social, political, and aesthetic shift reminiscent of that during the post-Industrial Revolution/pre-WWII epoch that launched the historical avant-garde.  This class, while exploring significant artistic and sociopolitical developments of the historical avant-garde, will primarily concentrate on the experimental theatre and performance of the past 15 years—a contemporary avant-garde that “hinge[s] on a networked spatiality, rather than on linear teleology” and reflects a growing collective investment on part of audiences and artists alike in the work of a work of art.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Contemporary Avant-Garde
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1 or any 4.0 FCE

cmCourseInfo.description: A practical introduction to aspects of theatre production, with a module on scenic design. Working extensively in the Helen Gardiner Phelan Playhouse, the students form the core of the production team for Drama productions. Application Deadline is April 10th; see department website for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Production and Design II: Design
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1, Minimum CGPA of 2.7 or permission of the Drama Centre.  See online application for details.
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 or any course from Group A

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on an audition, interview and/or portfolio submission. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. First round of applications were due March 10th for auditions & interviews held in April. The second round of applications are due by August 10th and auditions & interviews will be held in late August. Apply online: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Story-ing the Possible: Talking Treaties, Rehearsing (Re) conciliation

cmCourseInfo.description: This half course offers a comprehensive examination of Indigenous history in the territories (now called Canada), Treaty Relationships, and Indigenous-Settler Relationships, as they have shifted and evolved since first contact. Students will enter into conversation with this history and the contemporary issues confronting all Canadians today through the writings of Indigenous playwrights, oral history keepers, academic historians, and Indigenous theorists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Story-ing the Possible: Talking Treaties, Rehearsing (Re) conciliation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/​DRM101Y1/​UNI102Y1 or any 4.0 FCE

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth examination of selected performance disciplines, styles, and genres within their historical and critical context. Content may vary depending on instructor. Please consult the Undergraduate Drama office or check Studio Topics on our website for more details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Studio Practice
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1; DRM200Y1; Minimum CGPA of 2.7. See online application for details.
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM300Y1 or permission of the Centre.

notes.name: Course Note

To enrol in DRM375H1, you must take DRM300Y1 as a pre or co-requisite. To enrol in DRM300Y1 or for more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Special Topics in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies

cmCourseInfo.description:
An in-depth examination of selected issues in drama, theatre and performance studies.
Special Topics vary for Breadth distribution depending on the course content. Please consult the Undergraduate Drama office and check Special Topics on the website for more details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1 or any 4.0 FCE

courses.name: Independent Studies in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: A scholarly project at the 300 level proposed by the individual student in conversation with a member of faculty who is willing to act as supervisor. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: CGPA 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; 10 FCE; Specialist or Major in Drama; A written proposal; Independent study form signed by both student and faculty instructor to be submitted for approval to the Associate Director (undergraduate) before registration: August 1st for September start date; November 1st for January start date.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced voice training to refine the skills and concepts developed thus far in DRM200Y1 and DRM300Y1, focusing on performance. Techniques of articulation, speech, and rhetoric are studied. Taken in conjunction with DRM403Y1: Advanced Performance: Mainstage and DRM411H1: Advanced Concepts in Movement.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Concepts in Voice
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum CGPA of 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM300Y1; acceptance into DRM403Y1 or permission of the Centre
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Minimum CGPA of 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM300Y1; Acceptance into DRM403Y1 or permission from the instructor.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of advanced directing for the theatre. The class is centered on student directed productions, which are publically presented at the end of term. Emphasis is placed on the development of strong central concepts and realizing the production with imagination, collaboration and creativity. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. The Application Deadline is March 10th.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Directing
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Specialist or Major in Drama with a minimum CGPA of 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM302H1; DRM331H1; a written proposal and an interview in April.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Applications are due on March 10th preceding each academic year. Please apply online using the link: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login There will be additional tutorial times which will be held regularly. Dates and times to be determined based on student availability. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course, taught each year by a different visiting professional theatre director, offers upper-level theatre and performance studies students the opportunity to explore acting in a full-length production. Plays are selected to challenge students in a variety of diverse ways, exposing them to a full spectrum of theatre and performance genres and possibilities. The Application Deadline is March 10th.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Performance: Mainstage
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Specialist or Major in Drama with a minimum CGPA of 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM300Y1, 1 FCE from DRM375H1/DRM376H1/ DRM377H1/DRM378H1; An audition in April.
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: DRM401H1, DRM411H1 (or permission of the Centre).

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Applications are due on March 10th preceding each academic year. Please apply online using the link: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login There will be additional tutorial times which will be held regularly in the second term. Dates and times to be determined based on student availability. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced movement training to refine the skills and concepts developed thus far in DRM200Y1 and DRM300Y1, focusing on performance. Techniques of personal physical awareness, movement as a tool for discovery in acting processes, movement as communication in performance, ensemble work, and movement generation are studied. Taken in conjunction with DRM403Y1: Advanced Performance: Mainstage and DRM401H1: Advanced Concepts in Voice.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Concepts in Movement
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum CGPA of 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM300Y1; acceptance into DRM403Y1 or permission of the Centre
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Minimum CGPA of 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM300Y1; Acceptance into DRM403Y1 or permission from the instructor.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: A continuation of DRM328H1, concentrating upon the in-depth knowledge and practice of playwriting with an emphasis on advanced style and technique of writing for the stage. Students develop their own longer work through in-class exercises, one major written assignment, and the final public presentation. See Portfolio Guidelines for information on how to apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Playwriting
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum CGPA of 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1, DRM328H1 and a portfolio of writing samples due in November.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Selection is based on an portfolio submission. Apply online by November 10th. https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login There will be additional tutorial times which will be held regularly. Dates and times to be determined based on student availability. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Continues the exploration of design and production techniques. Students are given an opportunity to use their knowledge and skills from previous production courses on an advanced level. Students are expected to participate in Drama Centre productions in senior creative and leadership roles. Focus also includes the integration of digital technology into theatrical performance. The Application Deadline is March 10th for an interview in April.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Production and Design
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum CGPA of 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM254Y1 or DRM354Y1; and permission of the Drama Centre

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca

Timetable Instructions
A written proposal; Independent study form to be submitted for approval to the Associate Director (undergraduate) by November 1st for January start date. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.
